text: John Indermaur (November 24, 1851 – July 19, 1925) was a British lawyer and legal writer, with his writing focus was on common law. He is known for having written An Epitome of Leading Common Law Cases in 1875, Principles of Common Law in 1876, and The Student's Guide to Trusts and Partnerships in 1885. Indermaur qualified as a solicitor in 1874. He and his law partner, Charles Thwaites, had a law firm on Chancery Lane in the City of London and began teaching and writing about law together in 1884. Other legal works written by Indermaur include A Manual of the Principals of Equity, The Student's Guide to Procedure and Evidence, and Principals and Practice in Matters Appertaining to Conveyancing. ==Personal life== He was born on November 24, 1851, in Lyncombe, Bath to John George Indermaur and Mary Staple. His father's family, the In der Maur, descended from Switzerland. He was married to Jessie Margaret Dickson. He died on July 19th, 1925, in Camberwell House in Surrey, England. == References == Category:1852 births Category:1925 deaths Category:19th-century British lawyers Category:20th-century British lawyers Category:British solicitors Category:English legal writers Category:British male writers Category:British people of Swiss descent John Category:People from Bath, Somerset
